data.title: Marcos Pushes Philippine Unity as Duterte Slams Successor
data.meta_description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and his predecessor Rodrigo Duterte drew thousands of their supporters in separate rallies on Sunday, highlighting a deepening rift that may split the alliance of the country’s most powerful political families that won the 2022 election.
data.text:
Former leader warned successor against moves to change charter

Duterte’s son Sebastian sought Marcos’s resignation, CNN says

Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and his predecessor Rodrigo Duterte drew thousands of their supporters in separate rallies on Sunday, highlighting a deepening rift that may split the alliance of the country’s most powerful political families that won the 2022 election.

As Marcos unveiled a new slogan for his administration before a crowd that the government estimated at 400,000, the former leader Duterte led a gathering in his hometown in Davao where he warned his successor that he may suffer the same fate as his late dictator father if he pushes ahead with efforts to amend the Constitution. Marcos Sr. was ousted in a popular revolt in 1986, prompting the family’s exile in Hawaii.
